Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Dana Dolan of George Mason University to conduct an interdisciplinary research project in the Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences area during the summer of 2013 at Australian National University (ANU) in Canberra, ACT. The project title is "Governance for Climate Change Adaptation in Complex, Crossboundary, Social-Ecological Systems." The host scientist is Professor Stephen R. Dovers, Director of ANU's Fenner School of Environment and Society.

The goal of this study is to understand the evolution of institutional arrangements for long-term governance, in theory and in practice. Climate change is a scientifically and socially complex challenge marked by irreducible uncertainty, very long feedback cycles and significant variation at the local scale. Adaptation will require coordination and collaboration across multiple institutional boundaries and across multiple sectors. These requirements present novel challenges to traditional, hierarchical approaches to governing as well as to decentralized market approaches; networked governance theories may help explain emerging decision-making structures. This study responds to calls from the climate change research community for empirical research that analyzes place-based adaptation and that extends existing work in the natural sciences to incorporate social sciences through a qualitative case study of the public policy networks in the Murray-Darling Basin (MDB) region in southeast Australia, an ecologically rich, politically fragmented, and institutionally diverse Social-Ecological System (SES). Furthermore, this research may provide insights for the literature on institutional change, broadly defined. Traditional theories such as punctuated equilibrium have provided a wealth of insight into how institutional change occurs-or is resisted-in complex public policy areas: governance through reaction to crises. However, the long-term crisis of climate change threatens to produce events ("punctuations") with unacceptable consequences in terms of human suffering. Developing alternative models of institutional change that support proactive approaches to long-term governance issues may help reduce these negative consequences.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Results of this study will be documented in a research report suitable for peer-reviewed publication. Findings will also be presented at national conferences and local seminars or workshops in both Australia and the United States with the aim of furthering cross-national policy learning and collaborative scholarship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this study was to understand the evolution of institutional arrangements for long-term governance, in theory and in practice. Specifically, I undertook field work in the Murray-Darling Basin (MDB) region in southeast Australia, an ecologically rich, politically fragmented, institutionally diverse, linked social and ecological system where long-term policy decisions are attempting to take the impacts of climate change into account. Climate change is a scientifically and socially complex challenge marked by irreducible uncertainty, very long feedback cycles and significant variations at the local scale. Adaptation will require coordination and collaboration across multiple institutional boundaries and across multiple sectors. These requirements present novel challenges to traditional, hierarchical approaches to governing, and also to decentralized market approaches such as water trading schemes, both of which are in use in the Murray-Darling and other regions around the world. At the same time, networked governance theories suggest that emerging decision-making structures play an important role in determining regional resilience.

My research focused on understanding the impact of network governance at the understudied intersection between centralized governments and local adaptation networks. Primary data was collected from nearly 50 open-ended interviews with organizations and key individuals involved in water governance in the region. An extensive set of secondary documents were also collected, including government reports and academic research that would have been difficult to locate from the US. These research sources, along with first-hand observations in the Australian capital of Canberra, at its national adaptation conference in Sydney, and during an extended trek along key natural habitats and food-producing regions along the River Murray, yielded a rich dataset for analysis.

The importance of this work stems from a pressing need to respond to the accelerating effects of climate change, and in particular for increasing the adaptive capacity in regional-scale SESs—a need made even more salient in light of Hurricane Sandy’s devastation. Developing pathways to governance challenges such as this required an assessment of various analysis frameworks for analyzing SESs, an appreciation of the diverse understandings of climate change adaptation held by members of relevant policy networks, and advancements in knowledge of networked governance perspectives on institutional change.

Initial findings suggest that (1) evaluating regional resilience is complicated by diverse understandings of what it means to adapt to climate change in general, versus responding to climate variability or adapting in a single sector such as water, and (2) understanding the dynamic relationship between centralized, hierarchical governments and decentralized adaptation networks offers important insights for increasing regional resilience.

While research analysis is ongoing as part of the researcher's doctoral dissertation, preliminary research results have been presented at conferences in Australia and the US, and a research paper is currently being prepared for a major international conference in Canada focused on networked governance. Other broader impacts included providing the PI a first-hand international research experience, an introduction to Australian science policy, and scientific infrastructure, and an orientation to its society, culture and governance institutions. These activities meet the NSF goal of ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce through early career opportunities for international education and collaboration.
